comments.commentBody:
It actually comes across less awkward than you think.

One essential difference is that science (absent Occam's Razor) can sustain multiple competing theories simultaneously. As long as each satisfies current and past observations, they are good until experiment eliminates one (or all) of them. I think this is perhaps what you mean by "just do it".

Philosophy and especially math cannot sustain this. Being purely deductive in nature, contradiction anywhere equals a collapse of the whole structure. One only proceeds with assured steps, never tentative.

That science utilizes induction via observation is what allows for tentative logical stepping. Of course the hope is that experimentation will eventually prune away all false paths. In that end we would also be left with an entirely consistent logical structure, just arrived at in different fashion.

Math of course is the extreme form of deductive stepping, with each piece of the puzzle truly cemented in. The tradeoff however is that the range of "askable" questions is very restricted (yet still mind-bogglingly vast!)

Science too is restricted, to the (sharable) observed. The unobserved (or unshared observed) is beyond addressing.

Perhaps the greatest benefit from philosophy is that it allows for the expression of heretofore inarticulate ideas and concepts. It is the least restricted in what it can ask, limited perhaps by imagination alone.

We don't believe in scientific theories, we accept them or not based on the evidence. Perhaps that's what you meant, or maybe you recognize that it takes faith to believe in evolution.

Since a Christian discovered genetics, (Mendel), it is likely that people of faith believe that God created evolutionary mechanisms.

But, how do you define evolution? Change over time? Or, does it mean that life, starting from the simplest reproducing cell "evolved" into all of the various forms of life that we can observe today and in the fossil record?

If by evolution you mean the latter, the evidence my friend, is weak.
Not likely to be effective, unfortunately. Of course they believe God is powerful enough to create Evolution. They just don't believe he did, because of, you know, the Bible.

DaveW, simply asserting the evidence is weak doesn't make it so. There is so much evidence that there is not enough room to even begin to list it here, but the documentation is in any library and also available from any number of Internet sites - and I mean dependable ones. If I may offer advice from a source you might endorse: tolle lege.
For people of faith who don't believe in Evolution, ask them if they believe God isn't powerful enough to create Evolution.

Thank you, American Girl, for your eloquent and on-target description of the hypocrisy imbedded in the political detractors of this healthcare reform law. You've described the "entitlement" of these justices perfectly. They have the Cadillac plans for life paid by  the common folk, the taxpayers who can't afford a modest health insurance for themselves or their children. So while these Justices and the GOP politicians have a "socialist" plan they adore, they decry such healthcare for the rest of the American population on the grounds that it's socialistic and therefore un-American. Same for the GOP "presidential" (I use the word loosely here) candidates, who with their final breaths will still be denying that government-sponsored  healthcare (like their own) is a right all Americans--not just themselves--should have.
Thank-you American girl nothing else need be said.

Please remember that all living active and retired Supreme Court justices receive Taxpayer Paid lifetime, gold plated, no questions asked, no cost too great for the American Taxpayer to bear, health, dental vision care for themselves and their spouses until their dying breath.  They never, ever have to create their own 'death panel' by having to choose between food and seeing a doctor, between making the rent or filling a prescription, no matter how vital.  You won't see the justices having a bake sale or putting out begging jars to pay for the medical bills of their children. They have absolutely no problem with socialized, universal health care for themselves and their families.  It's only the American Taxpayer, who is actually footing the bill!, whose health care needs are a threat to capitalism and our Constitution.  In this mind boggling hypocrisy the esteemed justices join their Republican brethren on Capital Hill at the public trough, gluttons all, while denying the very people who pay their salaries and their luxurious health care and pensions.

Economic growth in the West is a measure of the past. Sustainable and steady economies are the best we could hope for at this point. Of course, positive economic reports could still be filed to maintain the illusory confidence needed to maintain regional market vitality.

As for Greece, turning into America (i.e. an added a dose of American glut) would be the worst nightmare it could live through. Next to the USA, everyone else's average life-style is austere ! Krugman can keep face and insist otherwise, but he's just standing in the way of a global awakening.

There are no interviews with the people in your photos. their expressions are one of supreme grief.
one of your comments mentions 700 civilians killed by u.s. drone strikes. there have been no interviews here either. also, to my knowledge, no questioning of u.s. war planners as to the necessity or appropriateness of this as an other than battlefield tactic.
There is also suggestion of complicity with pakistan in these strikes. their war aims may be to knock out forces that are opposed to pakistani control of afghanistan, in a mistaken campaign to appease religious extremests inside pakistan by giving them afghanistan. or It could be sheer extension of pakistani military confrontations along their borders, as a way of showing toughness to would be enemies.
In appointing Mr. Holbrooke, Mr Obama showed he was looking for a settlement in Afghanistan that would end the hostilities in a way that would keep the peace. This was not to be. meanwhile the continued fighting made it more difficult, already made difficult by the bush administration's grossly mishandling the situation after the initial invasion. You have lots of comments that Afghanistan is not ready for "civil society". i would disagree. The western alliance, led by the u.s., did not put the necessary effort into this.
Civil society rests on peaceful pursuits, not military overkill. As you can see, the bush republicans continue to show that in many ways they don't even believe in this at home.
I wonder if the soldier will truly be punished. How many other crimes committed by American soldiers where the person was truly punished instead of being slapped on the wrist!

Fareed Zackaria made a striking point on what the US is doing in Afghanistan, building a police force, an army and a government infrastructure that the country with its meager resources, even projected to the illusion propoetions, could never afford; reminds me of the wall street financial schemes to have poor people buy houses, even mansions, they could not afford only  to promote the "business" to get their commissions. That is the bottom line of this total absurdiy

This is what you call a (hideously) ethnocentric lead:

"A United States service member methodically killed at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, in southern Afghanistan early Sunday, igniting fears of a new wave of anti-American hostility. . ."

Somebody kills 16 people, nine of them children, and the Times is worried about the public relations value of the event. Par for the corpse with the Times, the US, and our thoroughly rotten century-long policy of endless war on brown people everywhere.

Let's close down the 800 military bases, plow the half of our economy that feeds the war machine into things we need, and get on with building a sane world while we still have a quarter of a chance.

Give Afghanistan back to the Afghanistan Peoples & Cultures... It is the Graveyard of Empires. US should have learned from the Russians.  I really can't believe the stupidly of those in Power..Not everyone can be Bought!

The opening of this article says it all. The mass murder of Afghani civilians by a US sergeant evokes what---sadness at needless death and suffering? Compassion for the survivors? No, merely "fears of a new wave of anti-American hostility."

@".....fears of a new wave of hostility against Americans.."

Same old story. Fears of hostility against Americans. How about fears of local population, they are getting killed more than often by people who "protecting them".

This is terrorist act, it's not move of "insane person", this is not "accident". This soldier/fanatic should be locked in Guantanamo among others who think that killing civilians is OK. But, knowing situation, this terrorist will get "honorable discharge".

Soldiers in combat and off duty close to the combat zone are always under a lot of stress. We still don't know the real story here - what happened, who was there, was this soldier alone, were they on patrol? etc. In the 1st place, I would never trust anything with Karzai's name attached. The whole thing could be a total scam - a frame-up.  It would not be the first time,  a Gulf of Tonquin in reverse. When the fog clears we will know more. Of course it is terrible for Afghans, the US, GB and coalition forces whenever they lose people - that is part of the nature of war. The wrong thing to do now would be to exit en mass and do precisely what the Iranians want. Freedom loving nations need troops on the ground, and lots more of them in this neighborhood. The battle is only just taking shape and to draw down would be a big mistake. Afghanistan has been in a state of war since time immemorial. This is how the people of this nation live and die. The Taliban and Allies know this and cynically manipulate the morally relativistic issues around this problem - hence the conundrum : stay or go. The answer is - commit big time and fight - all the way to Tehran. That is where peace in Eurasia lies, hidden, covered with a thousand daggers, but there.

Time to leave, plain and simple.

What more do we need to tell us that we have overstayed our time in Afghanistan - by about 5 years?

I recently had a chance to talk with a verteran of Afghanistan and Iraq. He told me that the soldiers that are there now are not fighting for any "high" order reason like giving the Afghans a chance at Freedom-they are fighting to keep their buddies alive. With the conditions he told me about (no shower for weeks on end-ugh!) and C-rations that burst in their bags because of the hot temperatures  and the number of times the men and women have had to retrun to this nightmare-is it any wonder that one person miight go berserk!? What we are doing is not right for the Afghans and it is not right for our service men and women and it is not the proper policy for this country! Bring the soldiers home-not in 2014 but as soon as we can NOW!!!!!!

If a family member of one of those dead children made it into an American crowd here or elsewhere and blew everyone up, we would say he was "a fanatic".

So easy to see our pain, so difficult to understand the pain of others. But then again, we are the good guys.

Its nauseating to read comments that suggest psychological pressure, depression etc as provocative factors leading up to this guy's actions. I don't deny that the guy has issues but the overwhelming lack of condemnation for the soldier's actions is pure hypocrisy.

Turn the tables with an Aghan soldier killing 16 Americans (including children) at a war stricken area. See how many of you come with the same diagnosis or even suggest anything other than short of labelling him blood thirsty terrorist.

It is just sad.
No big deal. This will fade in 2 to 4 weeks
If he pleads guilty he can avoid the death penalty. Psych help is hard to find over there. Good luck brother.

Why is anyone upset?

This soldier has only done what Bush did when he invaded Iraq, illegally and without justification, causing the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent civilians including many girls under the age of 6.

And Obama continues raining rockets down on civilian areas of countries we're not even at war with, killling yet more civilians, and yes, girls under the age of 6.

Worse, they have been torturing innocent civilians including those of your nearest allies like Canadian businessman Maher Arar who was tortured for a year in a cell the size of a coffin! A Canadian businessman! Tortured by American troops. For a Year! In a cell the sie of a coffin!

This soldier is only doing what he's been taught by your violent culture, celebration of guns, glorification of murder and mayhem and torture and base venality difficult for any modern mind to comprehend, all the while prating on about god and religion and America the Beautiful.

But today, regardless of why when he has done nothing terribly original, the entire world sees clearly what you've become. A murderer, breaking into people's homes in the night, killing children, trying to hide the evidence.

Once there was no country more admired. But today your name is Ozymandias. Look on your own works, all ye so-called Mighty, and despair. For this is the destination you embarked on twelve long years ago. I hope you enjoy it.

Never mind that these "Villagers" have been shooting at him for months... while hiding behind their Wives and Children. hoping some are killed for a "Photo OP". All Taliban and Al-Qaeda are Civilians...100% of them. Maybe this Soldier was tired of his Religion being Insulted and Dumped on by Muslims, American Comedians, and American Politicians.Maybe this Soldier was sick of having his Rights taken away to Appease Islamofascists.Maybe this Soldier was tired of his Commander -in- Chief and Generals playing games with his life and the lives of his friends.

Perhaps Merkel actually believes that the austerian policies forced upon the Greeks and other southern Europeans, as well as the Irish, will work.  It is more likely, however, that she is unwilling to confront German public opinion, which has rebelled at the kind of transfers that are required to rescue Greece and other peripheral EU members, despite Germany having been the major beneficiary of intra-EU trade for many years.  German banks are also prime actors in the property bubbles that have engulfed southern Europe.  Still, how badly does a policy have to fail before its proponents admit that it isn't working?   If Hollande becomes president of France in May, as is likely, Merkel will lose her partner, Sarkozy, in forcing Greece and other states to agree to their impoverishment.  Hollande has already said he opposes austerian economics.  What happens if the EU can no longer maintain the kind of united front that Merkel and Sarkozy have engineered?  Already the IMF's Lagarde has broken ranks.  Who is next?

HiYa Jane, me darlin, I bow to your brains, fair lady, after coming across two words that this so-called "wordsmith" has only occasionally seen in print, but never bothered to seek the meaning of, I'm referring to "contretemps and picayune"...just goes to show, one is never to old to learn something new and being I now have a seat at the WP Round Table, there will be countless many more I'll need to look up!
As for John and myself, yours truly is exceedingly gratified he regards me as an equal in this creme de la creme coterie on the blogosphere and that also takes in all my other fellow WP'ers who treat me with the same admirable acceptance.
I hope no one gets tired of my bringing this up from time to time, as I honestly believe it's somehow a beautiful dream I'm in the midst of having.
Have a great week, Jane, and everyone else who reads this.

WHH aka Howie
Sad indeed.

Those who insist on having their REAL meat would be much edified by killing an animal, cutting thru the abdomen, pulling out the guts (careful cutting around anus for tie-off to avoid spillage), sawing off appendages, yanking off the hide/skin, and slicing up the muscle groups into "cuts of meat". Then, enjoy.
Any other approach to carnivory is ignorance-based and self-delusional.

I wonder if it is like "Chicken Little" - the artificial food everybody will eat in the future as described in The Space Merchants by Frederik Pohl?  A really good book of a time when the only place left to go on vacation is the South Pole. and when really precious jewellery is made of wood since all trees have long since vanished from the earth.
